Utilities for handling networking sockets with a maximal amount of configuration possible intended.

  * [ #network ](https://crates.io/keywords/network)
  * [ #socket ](https://crates.io/keywords/socket)

about 1 month ago 
v1.63.0 
[ MIT ](https://choosealicense.com/licenses/mit) OR [ Apache-2.0 ](https://choosealicense.com/licenses/apache-2.0)

content.raw_markdown:
[](https://docs.rs/socket2/latest/socket2/all.html "show sidebar")
# Crate socket2Copy item path
[Settings](https://docs.rs/socket2/latest/settings.html)
[Help](https://docs.rs/socket2/latest/help.html)
Summary[Source](https://docs.rs/socket2/latest/src/socket2/lib.rs.html#9-745)
Expand description
Utilities for creating and using sockets.
The goal of this crate is to create and use a socket using advanced configuration options (those that are not available in the types in the standard library) without using any unsafe code.
This crate provides as direct as possible access to the system’s functionality for sockets, this means little effort to provide cross-platform utilities. It is up to the user to know how to use sockets when using this crate. _If you don’t know how to create a socket using libc/system calls then this crate is not for you_. Most, if not all, functions directly relate to the equivalent system call with no error handling applied, so no handling errors such as [`EINTR`](https://doc.rust-lang.org/nightly/std/io/error/enum.ErrorKind.html#variant.Interrupted "variant std::io::error::ErrorKind::Interrupted"). As a result using this crate can be a little wordy, but it should give you maximal flexibility over configuration of sockets.
## [§](https://docs.rs/socket2/latest/socket2/#examples)Examples
```
use std::net::{SocketAddr, TcpListener};
use socket2::{Socket, Domain, Type};
// Create a TCP listener bound to two addresses.
let socket = Socket::new(Domain::IPV6, Type::STREAM, None)?;
socket.set_only_v6(false)?;
let address: SocketAddr = "[::1]:12345".parse().unwrap();
socket.bind(&address.into())?;
socket.listen(128)?;
let listener: TcpListener = socket.into();
// ...
```

### [§](https://docs.rs/socket2/latest/socket2/#features)Features
This crate has a single feature `all`, which enables all functions even ones that are not available on all OSs.
## Structs[§](https://docs.rs/socket2/latest/socket2/#structs)

[Domain](https://docs.rs/socket2/latest/socket2/struct.Domain.html "struct socket2::Domain")
    Specification of the communication domain for a socket.

[MaybeUninitSlice](https://docs.rs/socket2/latest/socket2/struct.MaybeUninitSlice.html "struct socket2::MaybeUninitSlice")
    A version of [`IoSliceMut`](https://doc.rust-lang.org/nightly/std/io/struct.IoSliceMut.html "struct std::io::IoSliceMut") that allows the buffer to be uninitialised.

[MsgHdr](https://docs.rs/socket2/latest/socket2/struct.MsgHdr.html "struct socket2::MsgHdr")
    Configuration of a `sendmsg(2)` system call.

[MsgHdrMut](https://docs.rs/socket2/latest/socket2/struct.MsgHdrMut.html "struct socket2::MsgHdrMut")
    Configuration of a `recvmsg(2)` system call.

[Protocol](https://docs.rs/socket2/latest/socket2/struct.Protocol.html "struct socket2::Protocol")
    Protocol specification used for creating sockets via `Socket::new`.

[RecvFlags](https://docs.rs/socket2/latest/socket2/struct.RecvFlags.html "struct socket2::RecvFlags")Non-Redox
    Flags for incoming messages.

[SockAddr](https://docs.rs/socket2/latest/socket2/struct.SockAddr.html "struct socket2::SockAddr")
    The address of a socket.

[SockRef](https://docs.rs/socket2/latest/socket2/struct.SockRef.html "struct socket2::SockRef")
    A reference to a [`Socket`](https://docs.rs/socket2/latest/socket2/struct.Socket.html "struct socket2::Socket") that can be used to configure socket types other than the `Socket` type itself.

[Socket](https://docs.rs/socket2/latest/socket2/struct.Socket.html "struct socket2::Socket")
    Owned wrapper around a system socket.

[TcpKeepalive](https://docs.rs/socket2/latest/socket2/struct.TcpKeepalive.html "struct socket2::TcpKeepalive")
    Configures a socket’s TCP keepalive parameters.

[Type](https://docs.rs/socket2/latest/socket2/struct.Type.html "struct socket2::Type")
    Specification of communication semantics on a socket.
## Enums[§](https://docs.rs/socket2/latest/socket2/#enums)

[InterfaceIndexOrAddress](https://docs.rs/socket2/latest/socket2/enum.InterfaceIndexOrAddress.html "enum socket2::InterfaceIndexOrAddress")
    A local interface specified by its index or an address assigned to it.

# Socket2
Socket2 is a crate that provides utilities for creating and using sockets.
The goal of this crate is to create and use a socket using advanced configuration options (those that are not available in the types in the standard library) without using any unsafe code.
This crate provides as direct as possible access to the system's functionality for sockets, this means little effort to provide cross-platform utilities. It is up to the user to know how to use sockets when using this crate. _If you don't know how to create a socket using libc/system calls then this crate is not for you_. Most, if not all, functions directly relate to the equivalent system call with no error handling applied, so no handling errors such as ``EINTR``. As a result using this crate can be a little wordy, but it should give you maximal flexibility over configuration of sockets.
See the [API documentation](https://docs.rs/socket2) for more.
# Branches
Currently Socket2 supports two versions: v0.5 and v0.4. Version 0.5 is being developed in the master branch. Version 0.4 is developed in the [v0.4.x branch](https://github.com/rust-lang/socket2/tree/v0.4.x) branch.
# OS support
Socket2 attempts to support the same OS/architectures as Rust does, see <https://doc.rust-lang.org/nightly/rustc/platform-support.html>. However this is not always possible, below is current list of support OSs.
_If your favorite OS is not on the list consider contributing it! See[issue #78](https://github.com/rust-lang/socket2/issues/78)._
### Tier 1
These OSs are tested with each commit in the CI and must always pass the tests. All functions/types/etc., excluding ones behind the ``all`` feature, must work on these OSs.
  * Linux
  * macOS
  * Windows


### Tier 2
These OSs are currently build in the CI, but not tested. Not all functions/types/etc. may work on these OSs, even ones **not** behind the ``all`` feature flag.
  * Android
  * FreeBSD
  * Fuchsia
  * iOS
  * illumos
  * NetBSD
  * Redox
  * Solaris


# Minimum Supported Rust Version (MSRV)
Socket2 uses 1.63.0 as MSRV.
# License
This project is licensed under either of
  * Apache License, Version 2.0, ([LICENSE-APACHE](https://github.com/rust-lang/socket2/blob/97fb0ab8001d34318eeb3ed3830bc656b06eb8df/LICENSE-APACHE) or <https://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0>)
  * MIT license ([LICENSE-MIT](https://github.com/rust-lang/socket2/blob/97fb0ab8001d34318eeb3ed3830bc656b06eb8df/LICENSE-MIT) or <https://opensource.org/licenses/MIT>)


at your option.
### Contribution
Unless you explicitly state otherwise, any contribution intentionally submitted for inclusion in this project by you, as defined in the Apache-2.0 license, shall be dual licensed as above, without any additional terms or conditions.
#### Dependencies
~0–8.5MB  ~78K SLoC
  * [libc](https://lib.rs/crates/libc "0.2.171") unix
  * [windows-sys](https://lib.rs/crates/windows-sys "obsolete") 0.52[+Win32_Foundation](https://lib.rs/crates/windows-sys/features#feature-Win32_Foundation)[+Win32…WinSock](https://lib.rs/crates/windows-sys/features#feature-Win32_Networking_WinSock)[+Win32_System_IO](https://lib.rs/crates/windows-sys/features#feature-Win32_System_IO)[+Win32…Threading](https://lib.rs/crates/windows-sys/features#feature-Win32_System_Threading)[+Win32…WindowsProgramming](https://lib.rs/crates/windows-sys/features#feature-Win32_System_WindowsProgramming) win


#### [Other feature](https://lib.rs/crates/socket2/features)
  * [all](https://lib.rs/crates/socket2/features#feature-all)


  *[SLoC]: approx. additional lines of code

readme.raw_markdown:
[](https://docs.rs/socket2/latest/socket2/all.html "show sidebar")
# Crate socket2Copy item path
[Settings](https://docs.rs/socket2/latest/settings.html)
[Help](https://docs.rs/socket2/latest/help.html)
Summary[Source](https://docs.rs/socket2/latest/src/socket2/lib.rs.html#9-745)
Expand description
Utilities for creating and using sockets.
The goal of this crate is to create and use a socket using advanced configuration options (those that are not available in the types in the standard library) without using any unsafe code.
This crate provides as direct as possible access to the system’s functionality for sockets, this means little effort to provide cross-platform utilities. It is up to the user to know how to use sockets when using this crate. _If you don’t know how to create a socket using libc/system calls then this crate is not for you_. Most, if not all, functions directly relate to the equivalent system call with no error handling applied, so no handling errors such as [`EINTR`](https://doc.rust-lang.org/nightly/std/io/error/enum.ErrorKind.html#variant.Interrupted "variant std::io::error::ErrorKind::Interrupted"). As a result using this crate can be a little wordy, but it should give you maximal flexibility over configuration of sockets.
## [§](https://docs.rs/socket2/latest/socket2/#examples)Examples
```
use std::net::{SocketAddr, TcpListener};
use socket2::{Socket, Domain, Type};
// Create a TCP listener bound to two addresses.
let socket = Socket::new(Domain::IPV6, Type::STREAM, None)?;
socket.set_only_v6(false)?;
let address: SocketAddr = "[::1]:12345".parse().unwrap();
socket.bind(&address.into())?;
socket.listen(128)?;
let listener: TcpListener = socket.into();
// ...
```

### [§](https://docs.rs/socket2/latest/socket2/#features)Features
This crate has a single feature `all`, which enables all functions even ones that are not available on all OSs.
## Structs[§](https://docs.rs/socket2/latest/socket2/#structs)

[Domain](https://docs.rs/socket2/latest/socket2/struct.Domain.html "struct socket2::Domain")
    Specification of the communication domain for a socket.

[MaybeUninitSlice](https://docs.rs/socket2/latest/socket2/struct.MaybeUninitSlice.html "struct socket2::MaybeUninitSlice")
    A version of [`IoSliceMut`](https://doc.rust-lang.org/nightly/std/io/struct.IoSliceMut.html "struct std::io::IoSliceMut") that allows the buffer to be uninitialised.

[MsgHdr](https://docs.rs/socket2/latest/socket2/struct.MsgHdr.html "struct socket2::MsgHdr")
    Configuration of a `sendmsg(2)` system call.

[MsgHdrMut](https://docs.rs/socket2/latest/socket2/struct.MsgHdrMut.html "struct socket2::MsgHdrMut")
    Configuration of a `recvmsg(2)` system call.

[Protocol](https://docs.rs/socket2/latest/socket2/struct.Protocol.html "struct socket2::Protocol")
    Protocol specification used for creating sockets via `Socket::new`.

[RecvFlags](https://docs.rs/socket2/latest/socket2/struct.RecvFlags.html "struct socket2::RecvFlags")Non-Redox
    Flags for incoming messages.

[SockAddr](https://docs.rs/socket2/latest/socket2/struct.SockAddr.html "struct socket2::SockAddr")
    The address of a socket.

[SockRef](https://docs.rs/socket2/latest/socket2/struct.SockRef.html "struct socket2::SockRef")
    A reference to a [`Socket`](https://docs.rs/socket2/latest/socket2/struct.Socket.html "struct socket2::Socket") that can be used to configure socket types other than the `Socket` type itself.

[Socket](https://docs.rs/socket2/latest/socket2/struct.Socket.html "struct socket2::Socket")
    Owned wrapper around a system socket.

[TcpKeepalive](https://docs.rs/socket2/latest/socket2/struct.TcpKeepalive.html "struct socket2::TcpKeepalive")
    Configures a socket’s TCP keepalive parameters.

[Type](https://docs.rs/socket2/latest/socket2/struct.Type.html "struct socket2::Type")
    Specification of communication semantics on a socket.
## Enums[§](https://docs.rs/socket2/latest/socket2/#enums)

[InterfaceIndexOrAddress](https://docs.rs/socket2/latest/socket2/enum.InterfaceIndexOrAddress.html "enum socket2::InterfaceIndexOrAddress")
    A local interface specified by its index or an address assigned to it.

    A reference to a `Socket`⟨17⟩ that can be used to configure socket types other than the `Socket` type itself.

Socket⟨17⟩
    Owned wrapper around a system socket.

TcpKeepalive⟨18⟩
    Configures a socket’s TCP keepalive parameters.

Type⟨19⟩
    Specification of communication semantics on a socket.
## Enums§⟨20⟩

InterfaceIndexOrAddress⟨21⟩
    A local interface specified by its index or an address assigned to it.

enriched_crate.readme_summary: The `socket2` crate provides utilities for creating and configuring sockets with advanced options not available in Rust's standard library, while avoiding unsafe code. It offers direct access to system socket functionality, enabling fine-grained control over domains, protocols, and socket types, along with features like TCP keepalive configuration and advanced message handling. The crate prioritizes flexibility over cross-platform abstractions and includes a single feature flag (`all`) to enable functions specific to certain operating systems.
enriched_crate.factual_counterfactual:
### Pair 1: Socket Creation and Configuration
✅ Factual: The `socket2` crate allows users to create and configure sockets with advanced options, such as specifying the communication domain (`Domain`) and type (`Type`) without relying on unsafe code.  
❌ Counterfactual: The `socket2` crate automatically handles common socket errors like `EINTR` and provides built-in error recovery mechanisms to simplify socket programming.

---

### Pair 2: Cross-Platform Features
✅ Factual: The `socket2` crate provides direct access to system-level socket functionality but does not prioritize cross-platform abstractions, leaving platform-specific behavior to the user.  
❌ Counterfactual: The `socket2` crate includes comprehensive cross-platform utilities that abstract away all platform-specific differences in socket behavior.

---

### Pair 3: TCP Keepalive Configuration
✅ Factual: The `TcpKeepalive` struct in the `socket2` crate enables users to configure TCP keepalive parameters, such as idle time and interval, for fine-grained control over socket behavior.  
❌ Counterfactual: The `TcpKeepalive` struct automatically enables TCP keepalive for all sockets created using the `socket2` crate, regardless of user configuration.
